Since most people here haven't had their opinions changed (excepting a few people who went from ambiguous to pro-life), I have been wondering why else people post here.
I post here to better understand the reasons behind the pro-life position and to present my own conditional pro-choice arguements both in the hope of convincing others and to let my views stand up to scrutiny (so that I could adapt them if I heard a reasonable opposing arguement).

I went from ambivalent to pro-life (as did a few I know) but not on these forums. "Pro choice" seems to cover a large spectrum of inconsistent thinking which is why I am not surprised by this.
That brings up an interesting question. Namely, what is the precise distinction between pro-life and pro-choice? Does it mean that a pro-life view is defined as one which would outlaw abortion in all trimesters, except possibly for a few exceptions for rape/incest/risk of mother's life, and then pro-choice would be everyone else? That seems to be the working definition. With such a definition, no wonder that you are labelling "Pro choice" thinking as inconsistent - there are a lot more possible pro-choice variations than there are pro-life variations. As someone who is pro-life, do you know what variations there are in the pro-life view or, indeed, does it leave any room for varied opinions?
 
 I would love to see more discussion of views that are in between the two extremes of abortion illegal at all times, and abortion allowed at all times. My own view is between the two, closer to the pro-choice side.
 
 By the way, from curiousity, what made you change from ambivalent to pro-life?

cell_death

Yes, it is interesting how we draw an arbitary "legal line in the sand" with regards to determining how late into a pregnancy an elective abortion is available.
But how can we make rules without legal lines in sand? At least its better than an illegal line.
Another opinion

But how can we make rules without legal lines in sand? At least its better than an illegal line.
The trouble is that nearly all of the discussion in the abortion debate sets that legal line in the sand at one of two points - at conception (meaning no abortion allowed) or at birth (meaning abortion always allowed). This is far too restrictive. Once could set that "legal line in the sand" anywhere within the ~9 months of pregnancy. Why do we restrict ourselves to those two extremes? Is it simply out of fear of the slippery slope - "give an inch, they'll take a mile"? If so, then that would be tragic.
 
 The trouble is that both sides have emotionally charged arguements to present. The emotional draw to the pro-life side relies on sympathy for the fetus. I, and probably most pro-choice supporters, can understand the empathy that pro-life people have for a late term fetus. There isn't much difference after all between a fetus one day before birth and a newly born baby. However, that sympathy mostly disappears when you are talking about a newly fertilized egg. It's hard to feel the same sense of empathy to a batch of a dozen cells soon after conception - that has no mind, emotions, thought, sense of pain, etc. That is why the pro-life movement almost invariably uses images of late-term fetuses to draw emotional support - not early embryos. As for the emotional draw of the pro-choice movement, most people can sympathize with a person's sense of rights over their own body. I suspect that such sympathy is lacking among pro-life supporters since they feel that those women who would want an abortion are morally "bad" and deserve any suffering brought about by carrying an unwanted pregnancy to term. 
 
 If pro-life proponents would be willing to stop at outlawing only late-term abortions, then a much higher percentage of Americans might support that. Unfortunately, pro-life sticks to the extreme of no abortions. Pro-choice supporters are afraid of incremental laws restricting abortion mostly out of fear of that slippery slope.
Sigma

If pro-life proponents would be willing to stop at outlawing only late-term abortions, then a much higher percentage of Americans might support that. Unfortunately, pro-life sticks to the extreme of no abortions. Pro-choice supporters are afraid of incremental laws restricting abortion mostly out of fear of that slippery slope.

 
 This is the sticking point, however. Since most of the pro-life proponents have religious dogma as their justification, there is no compromise on this issue. The majority of America would be willing to restrict late term abortions, according to polls, and pro-choice people are among them. However, there is no compromise with the pro-life position.
 
 Pro-choice people do not all draw the line at birth, as I do. There is a wide range, such as yourself.
simone

That brings up an interesting question. Namely, what is the precise distinction between pro-life and pro-choice? . . . . abortion allowed at all times. . . . 
I am a pro-choice and I am certainly not in favor of "abortion allowed at all times," and I am very sure that a majority of those who call themselves pro-choice hold essentially the same opinion. Only a very small minority of pro-choice folks are in favor of abortion at every stage of a pregnancy.
 
 It is also to be remembered that those who are pro-choice support a woman's decision to continue a pregnancy. Most of us also support a system of support for women who make such decisions when they encounter economic or health problems as a result of their decisions.
Another opinion

This is the sticking point, however. Since most of the pro-life proponents have religious dogma as their justification, there is no compromise on this issue. The majority of America would be willing to restrict late term abortions, according to polls, and pro-choice people are among them. However, there is no compromise with the pro-life position.
 
 Pro-choice people do not all draw the line at birth, as I do. There is a wide range, such as yourself.

 It is interesting to note that, historically, there has been considerable variation in official church dogma on when abortions should be condemned as murder - ranging mostly from conception (i.e. always) to "quickening" (roughly the third trimester). In holding true to their father's beliefs, they are condemning the religious beliefs of their earlier ancestors (great-great-great Grandfathers, etc.).
 
 My own religious beliefs, such as they are, tells me that God would be cruel indeed to put a soul into a newly fertilized egg. Imagine the torture that such a soul would go through in those first months before the body is sufficiently formed.
Another opinion

I am a pro-choice and I am certainly not in favor of "abortion allowed at all times," and I am very sure that a majority of those who call themselves pro-choice hold essentially the same opinion. Only a very small minority of pro-choice folks are in favor of abortion at every stage of a pregnancy.
For you and other pro-choice people: If a law were being presented outlawing abortion in the last trimester (except for the usual exceptions of life/health of mother, rape and incest, as well as possible exceptions to abort severely damaged fetuses) and you could have trust that a "slippery slope" would not cause all abortions to be outlawed, would you support such a law banning third-trimester abortions? If you would find such a law too restrictive, how much would you be willing to restrict abortions? (Again, please only answer if you consider yourself pro-choice.)

OccamsRazor

For you and other pro-choice people: If a law were being presented outlawing abortion in the last trimester (except for the usual exceptions of life/health of mother, rape and incest, as well as possible exceptions to abort severely damaged fetuses) and you could have trust that a "slippery slope" would not cause all abortions to be outlawed, would you support such a law banning third-trimester abortions? If you would find such a law too restrictive, how much would you be willing to restrict abortions? (Again, please only answer if you consider yourself pro-choice.)

 
 Well, from a personal viewpoint this is roughly the position I support (which is also that of UK law). Elective abortion is legal until the 24th week of pregnancy, at which point the child has a good chance of surviving birth. After that time an abortion can only be granted on medical grounds or if the mother is judged to pose a threat to herself if denied an abortion. 
 
 This does still allow late term abortions to be carried out if the child is found to have a number of diseases/disorders that are judged to to severe enough. However, some allowances are controversial such as allowing a late abortion to be carried out if the child has a cleft pallet or Down's Syndrome for example- these being matters that I wouldn't claim to have a good answer too (having recently given much thought to as baby number 1 is on the way).
 
 I don't see a slippery slope issue to restriction of abortion services in the UK based upon this approach- if anything elective abortion may become less available in the future as neonatal care of very premature babies improves.

Every view is taken on faith my friend. Even your "reasoning" is based on logic that is taken on faith.
As a scientist, I usually assume that generally accepted scientific views are correct since they have a preponderance of proof, unlike religious views that depend on leaps of faith. By "reasoning", I refer to logical reasoning that does not need leaps of faith to understand or accept their veracity.
 
 That does not mean that I do not take religious leaps of faith - I do, though they are often hard to reconcile with scientific beliefs. However, I strongly believe that, in making laws that affect all people (not just those of a particular belief system), the reasoning behind these laws cannot include leaps of faith but be logically based on proveable concepts.

Science is faith as well. You first have faith that experiments (etc) done in the based are correct. You also have a faith in existence. Science has just as many assumptions as religion does. Everything is a matter of degree. The assumption that the world exists (as opposed to the idea that we are dreaming all of this) is a basic assumption that everyone in the world makes in order to survive. Even those who ponder its non-existence have to assume its existence to run their everyday lives, so denial of such basic things as the existence of the world or the existence of "equals" (which is an abstract concept devised by man, not an object - so its existence is automatic) is merely an academic exercise with no basis in reality.
 
 We have to have basic assumptions that what we observe is reality in order to live. Science is based on observeable experience and bad science is usually eventually weeded out through peer review. Religious faith simply makes assumptions without demanding any observeable proof or even self-consistency. Everything is explained by the convenient reason that God is all-powerful and that we cannot know his purposes. 
 
 If God actually did speak to me directly, then I might also believe in the improbable scenarios that most religious beliefs hold. Otherwise, we simply have the word of man that is supposed to be the word of God. Most of the time, given the corruptibility of human nature, I remain very skeptical when someone claims to know God's will.
OccamsRazor

Does this mean that the legal "line in the sand" will move as technology improves to care for even earlier premature babies? Also, given the current limit against third term abortions, what is the popular support in the UK for pushing that limit earlier?

 
 I would say yes, based on past evidence. The 1967 Abortion act originally allowed elective abortion up to the 28th week of pregnancy, but this was reduced to the 24th week in 1990 when the act was amended, much in light of advances in neonatal care. This law is based on the notion that a woman can choose to have an abortion up until the point where the child has a substantial chance of surviving birth and infancy, at which point the state recognises the baby as a legal person.
 
 In the 2004 Geenral Election the abortion issue received some publicity when the notion of reducing the elective limit to 22 or even 20 weeks was raised by a Catholic Bishop (IIRC). This then lead to predictably ambigious comments from the main party leaders when the media and press put the question to them regarding their opinion on the matter.
 
 Significantly, the proposition did not receive support from the British Medical Association who hold alot of clout in this debate so it very much fell by the wayside- the political parties would not oppose the will of the BMA on an issue like abortion.
 
 As for popular support for a reduction in access to abortion in the UK that is something that is harder to gauge. The Pro-life camp is much smaller here than in the US and lacks political influence (except through the Church) and the general outlook on the matter seems to be that the law has it more or less right as things currently stand. I'd say the majority of Christians in the UK are more inclined to see that there is no further liberalisation of abortion availability as opposed to chasing limitations on existing provisions.

You seem to be saying that an assumption that the world exists is the same level of assumption as saying that God created the world and man, Adam and Eve were the original parents of all mankind, earthquakes happen due to God's wrath, etc. These are very different levels of assumptions. One (the existence of the world) is consistent with every experience all humans have ever had. The other (religious dogma) lies purely in the realm of people's imaginations - i.e. No one can demonstrate that any of it is true, it is only assumed as true and imagined, not experienced. 
 
 Basically, the only way we can know the truth (as opposed to simply guessing it) is to experience it. Most things we know do come from the experience of others - where I trust scientists, you trust ancient sources written by men and the interpretation of modern men as to what they mean. The very large advantage of trusting scientists is that they show proof and this proof can be demonstrated time and time again.

In light of the vastness of the universe and the overwhelming mystery of existence, we know nothing. It is a metaphysical truth and quantum physics understanding.
I highly doubt that any of those philosophers had the courage of their convictions to actually fully and consistently live based on those doubts. One has to assume the existence of most things in order to live. Otherwise, why bother eating if food does not exist or even if your body does not exist. Why not walk off that cliff if you truly believe that it does not exist. There are things that are obvious to us from our experience. Our interpretation of the reasons behind our experiences may or may not be flawed but not the truth that we experienced them.
 
 By the way, how do you claim that it is quantum physics understanding? As a physicist, I am curious. Quantum physics simply says that we do not know the location or energy, etc. of any particle/object exactly - that there is always some built in tolerance to any measurement, even if the instrument were perfect. This is far from saying that we do not know anything.

Another opinion

While this thread is being derailed to metaphysical discussions, let me pose a more related question to all of those who consider themselves pro-life:
 
 Namely, is there any permanent compromise that you would be willing to make in your position in order to make some progress on the issue? This is assuming that you could be sure that it would not lead to a "slippery slope" of opponents using your compromise to justify keeping all abortions legal.
Another opinion

As for popular support for a reduction in access to abortion in the UK that is something that is harder to gauge. The Pro-life camp is much smaller here than in the US and lacks political influence (except through the Church) and the general outlook on the matter seems to be that the law has it more or less right as things currently stand. I'd say the majority of Christians in the UK are more inclined to see that there is no further liberalisation of abortion availability as opposed to chasing limitations on existing provisions.
That makes me wonder how the balance would shift here in the US if third trimester abortions were mainly outlawed (with the usual exceptions). We on the pro-choice side are often afraid of the slippery-slope but there might actually be a political advantage to a third-term abortion restriction law being introduced. Namely, much of the emotional appeal of the pro-life movement would be satisfied with such a move. It would be much harder for pro-life proponents to show images of first-trimester embryos/fetuses to gain proponents since such images hold much less emotional appeal, whereas the emotional appeal of pro-choice proponents (in having women have rights over their own bodies) would still stand.

I highly doubt that any of those philosophers had the courage of their convictions to actually fully and consistently live based on those doubts. Why not walk off that cliff if you truly believe that it does not exist. There are things that are obvious to us from our experience. Our interpretation of the reasons behind our experiences may or may not be flawed but not the truth that we experienced them.

 
 We agree. "One has to assume the existence of most things in order to live." It becomes a semantic discussion. You prefer the word "assume", I prefer the word "believe": same thing.
 
 
By the way, how do you claim that it is quantum physics understanding? As a physicist, I am curious. Quantum physics simply says that we do not know the location or energy, etc. of any particle/object exactly - that there is always some built in tolerance to any measurement, even if the instrument were perfect. This is far from saying that we do not know anything.
I specifically used the term quantum physic's "understanding", a rather tortured turn of phrase. Every quantum physicist (at least the ones I am familiar with) agrees that any theory - and any aspect of any theory - is only that: a theory. They are always proving and disproving theories. They never raise theory to the level of fact. Einstein refers to it as "mystery"; Hawking refers to it as "the mind of God". In addition, Hawking said, "the actual point of creation lies outside the scope of presently known laws of physics." Professor Alan Guth from MIT, says the "instant of creation remains unexplained." Einstein spoke of what he called "the necessity for a beginning" and "the presence of a superior reasoning power." 
 
 Nobel Prize winning physicist, Leon Lederman in his book The God Particle says:
 
 In the very beginning, there was a void, a curious form of vacuum, a nothingness containing no space, no time, no matter, no light, no sound. Yet the laws of nature were in place and this curious vacuum held potential. A story logically begins at the beginning, but this story is about the universe and unfortunately there are no data for the very beginnings--none, zero. We don't know anything about the universe until it reaches the mature age of a billion of a trillionth of a second. That is, some very short time after creation in the big bang. When you read or hear anything about the birth of the universe, someone is making it up--we are in the realm of philosophy. Only God knows what happened at the very beginning.
 
 Most major quantum physicists reach the point where they confront the inexplicable: that which cannot be reduced or quantified. Hawking says: "Even if there is only one possible unified theory, it is just a set of rules and equations. What is it that breathes fire into the equations and makes a universe for them to describe?"
 
 That is all I was saying with that tortured turn of phrase.
Another opinion

We agree. "One has to assume the existence of most things in order to live." It becomes a semantic discussion. You prefer the word "assume", I prefer the word "believe": same thing.
 But, once again, not all assumptions are based on the same level of evidence. I choose the word "assume" since the word "believe" has usually been used to denote assumption without proof, as is the case for religious beliefs. The assumption that the world exists has nearly infinite amounts of proof in the everyday experiences of all human beings that ever lived. A bit of a difference - don't you think?

But, once again, not all assumptions are based on the same level of evidence. I choose the word "assume" since the word "believe" has usually been used to denote assumption without proof, as is the case for religious beliefs. The assumption that the world exists has nearly infinite amounts of proof in the everyday experiences of all human beings that ever lived.
Not at all. There is no evidence whatsoever for the existence of the world. The existence of the world is merely a model that explains our experiences and which we find psychologically managable. There is no reason idealism is any weaker than realism: in fact it postulates less things, which Occam would have approved of.
 
 We have never observed a world that exists seperate of observation. We have never observed a single law of physics, or even Cause and Effect operating, just created the model from experiences. 
 
 Of course we can't live like this: the philosopher who best revealed these gaps in our knowledge, David Hume, himself satirises those who claim not to believe anything, asking if they drink arsenic as readily as port or leave the room by the window as often as the door. But we must accept that no worldview is inherently 'rational' or 'provable'.

Depends what the truth is about. As Pilate said: 'what is truth?'
 
 Experience can tell us that we're having a subjective experience. It can confirm that there is a thinker, or rather a momentary experiencer.
 
 I can't think of any way of accessing 'truth' about an objective world when we have a subjective POV. That's why we have to make assumptions and understand why we're making them and that we have made them, rather than pretending we can be objective.
Another opinion

Depends what the truth is about. As Pilate said: 'what is truth?'
 
 Experience can tell us that we're having a subjective experience. It can confirm that there is a thinker, or rather a momentary experiencer.
 
 I can't think of any way of accessing 'truth' about an objective world when we have a subjective POV. That's why we have to make assumptions and understand why we're making them and that we have made them, rather than pretending we can be objective.
So, your claim is that there is no way for us to know the truth. Under such circumstances, all we can do is get as close to it as we can through a combination of our experiences and the experiences of all others. 
 
 That is where science has the advantage since everyone can measure the same thing given the same experimental set-up. The experience is the same for everyone and is repeatable over and over. With religion, no one (except possibly a very select few) has any experiences to confirm a particular belief or assumption. If one person claims to have an experience, he has no way of making others believe since they will not be able to experience it as well, no matter what their effort or knowledge is. With science, the experiences of one scientist can and are reproduced by other scientists. Otherwise, they are not fully trusted. Indeed, anyone can reproduce the results and believe for themselves (as long as they have the resources to reproduce the experiment and the knowledge to understand it). That is part of the essence of objectivity - anyone can have the same experience.

It is a semantic argument. The knowledge of the 15th Century is the joke of the 21st. Will the knowledge of the 21st Century be a joke to the 25th? Galileo was locked up based on the knowledge of his times. Pasteur was laughed at when he outlined his germ theory. History is full of stories of ideas that were ridiculed during their time only to be accepted later. Who knows if there will not be other beliefs to replace Galileo and Pasteur? As my friend Dan Boorstin said, "The problem was not ignorance, the problem was the illusion of knowledge.

The scientific method wasn't even really established in the 15th century. It had barely started in the 17th century and progressed in the 18th. It started really growing in the 19th century in terms of number of people pursuing science. Basically, growth in efforts in science had been growing exponentially until, say, mid-20th century. Just as in humans, the knowledge of a 5 year old is laughable compared to the knowledge of a 25 year old, but the knowledge of a 60 year old isn't all that much greater than that of a 25 year old, so with science. Science has passed its infancy. Most nagging inconsistencies have already been solved - at least those that affect the present. There are still unknowns - such as the beginnings of the universe and the search for a unified theory (that has most of its relevance at the beginning of the universe) but the great majority of physics that affect modern humans has already been theoretically answered. We are all just filling in the details.

I know it is not PC on these posts, but you know, I have been thinking about my last post. If one of my children were sick, I wouldn’t say, “Too bad, we can’t do anything about it.” I would take him or her to the doctor. Is that belief or assumption or hope? I don’t know. If the doctor helps her and she gets better, then he “knows” what he is doing. If she gets sicker, he is a quack. 
 
 From where I see I use the words “know anything” in a metaphysical, absolute sense, not in a human brain-informational sense. There is a school of thought that asks: Do you believe that the floor is there because you are standing on it, or are you standing on it because you believe it is there? Do we rocket into space because we knew how to do it or because we believed we could do it? Perhaps belief is not a static process. Perhaps, we create in mind and then it manifests materially. There are quantum physicists working with metaphysicians on this very subject. Does belief affect material manifestation? So, I can see the point of the saying that there are things we “know”, but I also see that in the metaphysical sense, we really don’t.
 
 I also don't know what this subject matter has to do with abortion and why it is posted under the "abortion" threads... I think we hijacked it and should give it back... perhaps someone has a thought from all this that we can open a new thread with.

I would take him or her to the doctor. Is that belief or assumption or hope? I don't know. If the doctor helps her and she gets better, then he "knows" what he is doing.  From where I see I use the words "know anything" in a metaphysical, absolute sense, not in a human brain-informational sense. There is a school of thought that asks: Do you believe that the floor is there because you are standing on it, or are you standing on it because you believe it is there? I can understand your point that, in the absolute, metaphysical sense, we can never be 100.00% sure of any of our knowledge. Just because all humans always have experienced the existence of the world, doesn't mean that it is 100.00% certain, just that the probability that it is true approaches 100.00% (say, 99.9999999%). The greater the amount of evidence, the closer that certainty is to 100.00%. That 0.0000001% leaves room for obsurd scenarios - such as that an omnicient being is causing us all to merely imagine our reality, or the scenario of the movie "The Matrix". These can be fun to ponder (especially in a social situation after a few drinks ;) ), but no one takes them seriously. If anyone did seriously live by the idea that the world may not exist, they would quickly do something stupid and die, or change their minds. 
 
 I, and most people, have a firm assumption, based on all of our and all human's experience, that the world that we live in exists and that our experiences of the moment are real. All the knowledge from Science has come from trusting mutual experience. It has gotten us far and will continue to (as long as we don't destroy ourselves in misusing that knowledge).
 
 From a quantum physics state, can our mental state make a truly impossible task possible? No one has ever showed that to have happened so I would say that it is 99.9999999% certain that it doesn't.

First, thanks sigma,
 
 I think that a huge impediment to the growth of us as individuals and our society in general is the belief that "we know" - whether that is on the left or on the right. We "know" that a fertilized ovum is a human being. We "know" that it is not. We "know" that the Bible was written by God. We "know" it was not. Etc., etc., etc. The belief that "we know" as opposed to "believe" puts us in an impossible position. We have no choice but to demand that others behave in accordance with what we "know" because it is crucial. If a fertilized ovum is a human being, we have to, at all costs, stop someone from harming that child. There is no choice. There are too many people who think they know too much.

Thomas Frank suggested something along this line in his book What's the matter with Kansas?. The Republican party uses emotionally charged issues such as Abortion, Gay Marriage, etc. to draw supporters while they simultaneously institute economic policies which generally are against the self-interest of those same supporters, whose attentions are drawn mainly to those emotionally charged issues. Howard Beale
Seems to me that Steeeeve is correct. The key word in his statement is the first one, "if". That is what the issue seems to be all about.
Sigma

If the unborn got all protections under the law and equal protection under the law (not referring to the 14th amendment here) then abortion would have to be illegal.

 
 

 Seems to me that Steeeeve is correct. The key word in his statement is the first one, "if". That is what the issue seems to be all about

 
 For this to be logically true, a person must currently have the right to live attached to another person against that other's will and without the other's consent. Then, and only then, would there be any case that equal protection would necessarily give the fetus this ability.
 
 Is this currently the case?
OccamsRazor

Is there truly such a thing as "3rd trimester elective abortion"?

 
 What I'm getting it is an abortion where the pregnancy is wanted anymore, for whatever reason, as opposed to one carried out on health grounds or because of a psychological issue with the mother (what was refered to as the "usual exceptions" by Another Opinion earlier).
 
 Thats what I'm thinking in theory... in practice I'm not sure how common such an abortion is.
Another opinion

Roe is not an all-or-nothing precedent, it only covers until viability. After that States can restrict it. Restricting late-term abortion would sit just fine, and the majority of the country would support such a move. 
This makes me wonder how many people really realize that Roe does not protect third-term abortions on demand. I have to admit that I wasn't clear on the issue either and my guess is that most people assume that Roe allows for on-demand abortions in all trimesters. Perhaps this is something that should be advertised so that the public can be educated on the issue - especially given the use of third-trimester abortion images by the pro-life movement to gather supporters. 
 
 My answer to the pro-life protesters in those states that have already outlawed third-term abortions would be "You XXXXXX ... abortion of fetuses that you show in those images has ALREADY been outlawed. Get a clue."
simone

You have to have a really, really good reason for getting a third-trimester abortion--or any abortion when the fetus becomes viable--threat of death or extreme injury if pregnancy continues, something extremely serious.
unkerpaulie

If the unborn got all protections under the law and equal protection under the law (not referring to the 14th amendment here) then abortion would have to be illegal.

 how could the unborn possibly get legal protection from any state? up to the day before the baby is born, the baby is a citizen of no country, and therefore no country is obligated to protect it. if on the day the baby is due, the mother goes to canada and the baby is born there, then the baby is a canadian citizen. up until the baby is born, the state is responsible for the welfare of the mother, which includes the welfare of the baby, but not vice versa.
 
 of course, "if" this was the case, that would make abortion illegal, but how could that possibly happen?
Steeeeve

why are you limiting things to states? I think people should be treated equally no matter where you are.
 
 The thing is, your so called "right to control your body" is gone once you place another person in the position where the could not survice otherwise. It is the mother forcing this upon the child...not the other way around.
Howard Beale

why are you limiting things to states? I think people should be treated equally no matter where you are.
 
 The thing is, your so called "right to control your body" is gone once you place another person in the position where the could not survice otherwise. It is the mother forcing this upon the child...not the other way around.
Who has the God given authority to take that God given right to dominion over your own body?
unkerpaulie

why are you limiting things to states? I think people should be treated equally no matter where you are.
 
 The thing is, your so called "right to control your body" is gone once you place another person in the position where the could not survice otherwise. It is the mother forcing this upon the child...not the other way around.

 when i say "state" i mean whatever country it is, not just america. regardless of the country the pregnant woman is in, the unborn child has no rights as a citizen until it is born and issued those rights by naturalization
 
 if the woman is at the stage in her pregnancy where she is not due yet, but her baby has a good chance of surviving outsdie her body, then i would be in favor of a method to take the baby out and put it in the custody of the state. it would have to remain under hospital care until it is developed enough to be ready for adoption. of course, even this would be the mother's decision, but having this option may prevent a lot of 3rd trimester abortions. most women would not want to opt for an abortion in the 3rd trimester because of the complications and risks, and also because theyve already invested a lot in the baby up to that point. with an option like that (which may be very costly to the government/hospital/medical insurance) at least another option is available other than 3rd trimester abortion
